United States Border Patrol Agent Ignacio Rodriguez Jr.
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the two checkpoints: Freer Immigration Checkpoint and Hebbronville Checkpoint
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.United States Border Patrol Agent Hugo B: United States Border Patrol Agent Hugo Benavides
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.United States Department of Homeland Sec: United States Department of Homeland Security
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.Fifth Circuit: United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the department: United States Department of Homeland Security
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.Supreme Court: Supreme Court of the United States
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.Agent Trevino: United States Border Patrol Agent Jorge Luis Trevino

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Magistrate Judge: judge who signed the Report and Recommendation, making recommendations based on articulable factors indicating that illegal activity might be afoot
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol: involved in the stop of RICARDO RODRIGUEZ, JR. and IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR.; considered the behavior of vehicles' drivers in determining reasonable suspicion to stop; followed suspicious vehicles for approximately five minutes; conducted a roving stop; familiar with most vehicles on Farm-to-Market Road 2050; interacted with law enforcement during the traffic stop; involved in the arrest and questioning of IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR.; location of questioning; had sufficient evidence to conclude that two vehicles were driving in tandem
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Freer Police Department: conducted a traffic stop, advised of a BOLO for a black Dodge pickup truck, had an officer named Officer Reyes who made contact with IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR.; issued a citation and impounded the vehicle due to unclear ownership and lack of insurance information; cooperated with United States Border Patrol during the traffic stop
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Court: held a hearing on the pending motions to suppress and considered factors for reasonable suspicion
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S. Highway 59: highway where vehicles were inspected by United States Border Patrol and location of Freer immigration checkpoint; location of the traffic stop; part of route used to avoid checkpoints
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Freer Immigration Checkpoint: location where Agent Trevino was stationed and conducted inspections; checkpoint avoided by smugglers; location where IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. was transported for further questioning
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Freer Immigration Checkpoint Building: building where Agent Trevino processed undocumented individuals
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Border Patrol Station Parking Lot: parking lot adjacent to the Freer immigration checkpoint
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol Agent Jorge: conducted inspections and processed undocumented individuals at the Freer immigration checkpoint; testified during the hearing about his experience with smuggling routes; explained that most vehicles he encounters are Ford F-150s or Ford F-250s, often used by oil companies; was unaware of the specific location of Corinth, Texas
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol Agent Ignaci: called out vehicles going southbound during Agent Trevino's shift, driver of the black Dodge pickup truck, was nervous during a traffic stop by Officer Reyes; provided inconsistent information about vehicle ownership
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Farm-to-Market Road 2050: road adjacent to the Border Patrol station parking lot where vehicles turned southbound and where drop-offs of undocumented individuals were noticed; used by smugglers to avoid checkpoints; primarily used by ranchers, oil trucks, and occasional small cars from a nearby wind farm; has intersections with Mills Bennett Road, San Pablo Road, and Santo Nino Road; location of the traffic stop; known to be a popular smuggling route
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hebbronville Checkpoint: checkpoint on U.S. Highway 359 avoided by smugglers; mentioned by Defendant as the starting point of his travel
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Highway 16: highway connecting to Houston or San Antonio, used by smugglers after avoiding checkpoints; accessible via San Pablo Road and Santo Nino Road; location of the traffic stop
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S. Highway 359: highway with Hebbronville checkpoint; part of route used to avoid checkpoints
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Freer Immigration Checkpoint and Hebbron: checkpoints avoided by smugglers using routes via Farm-to-Market Road 2050, U.S. Highway 59, and U.S. Highway 359
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hertz Dallas-Fort Worth: rental car company used by smugglers to avoid losing personal vehicles in case of being caught; registered a white Malibu sedan involved in the incident
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mills Bennett Road: dirt road intersecting Farm-to-Market Road 2050, approximately five to six miles south of the Freer immigration checkpoint
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.San Pablo Road: road extending east from Farm-to-Market Road 2050, near the wind farm and Moglia ranch house; provides access to Highway 16
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Moglia Ranch House: located near the wind farm and San Pablo Road, south of the Freer immigration checkpoint
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Stag Ranch Trailer: located near the wind farm and San Pablo Road, south of the Freer immigration checkpoint
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Santo Nino Road: also known as Dinn Ranch, extends east from Farm-to-Market Road 2050; provides access to Highway 16
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Dinn Ranch: also known as Santo Nino Road, extends east from Farm-to-Market Road 2050; provides access to Highway 16
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Officer Reyes: conducted a traffic stop of IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR., noticed he was nervous and shaking during the interaction; issued a citation and impounded the black Dodge pickup truck due to unclear ownership and lack of insurance information
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Interstate 35: highway that would be the most direct route from Laredo, Texas to Dallas, Texas
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Laredo, Texas: city mentioned as the starting point of IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR.'s travel plans
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Dallas, Texas: city mentioned as the destination of IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR.'s travel plans; location where a vehicle involved in the incident was registered
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.San Antonio: city mentioned as an alternative destination that could be reached via Highway 16
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Border Patrol Agent Hugo B: received a phone call from his supervisor regarding the traffic stop on Farm-to-Market Road 2050 of IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. and drove to Highway 16 and U.S. Highway 59; made contact with Officer Reymundo Reyes and approached IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR.; asked about Defendant's citizenship and travel plans; transported IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. to the Freer immigration checkpoint for further questioning
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Officer Reymundo Reyes: conducted a traffic stop, noticed IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. was extremely nervous; asked about contraband after searching for proof of insurance; questioned Defendant's travel plans and route taken from Laredo to Dallas via Interstate 35; informed Defendant that he wasn't going to allow the black Dodge pickup truck to continue to its destination
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Department of Homeland Sec: received information regarding attempted alien smuggling events; conducted interviews at the Freer immigration checkpoint; involved in the prosecution of individuals and bears the burden of proving that stops were constitutional
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Government: prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures, involved in the prosecution of individuals and bears the burden of proving that stops were constitutional; has a court system including the Fifth Circuit
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court of Appeals for the F: court that does not adhere to a bright line rule regarding proximity to the Mexico border; previously held that certain factors can add to reasonable suspicion, such as vehicle registration and route taken; addressed similar cases involving tandem vehicles and probable cause for arrest; noted that the order of vehicles in a smuggling venture is not significant
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S. Highway 277: highway with a checkpoint that can be avoided by taking Ranch Road 2523 north to Highway 377
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Highway 377: highway that can be used to avoid the checkpoint on Highway 277 by taking Ranch Road 2523 north to Highway 377
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Ranch Road 2523: road that can be used to avoid the checkpoint on Highway 277 by taking it north to Highway 377
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Highway 85: a common smuggling route that avoids immigration checkpoints
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States: country with lawful bounds for stops, governing principles for traffic stops and arrests
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Supreme Court of the United States: refused to authorize investigative interrogations at law enforcement stations on less than probable cause or consent
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Court: governing body for traffic stops and arrests, applying principles set out in Terry
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States District Judge: judge who conducts independent review of motions to suppress and reviews the findings, conclusions, and recommendations of the Magistrate Judge
defendant who appeared to concede that the route from Laredo, Texas to Dallas, Texas would be a convenient route for smugglers to take
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Ford Motor Company: a truck manufacturer whose vehicles are commonly used by oil companies and encountered by Agent Trevino during his inspections
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Corinth, Texas: suburb of Dallas, Texas; city approximately twenty to twenty-five miles north of Dallas, Texas
